Expectation1: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation1: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: They are about to enter the main prayer hall for Friday congregational worship.
Story:
I wiped the sweat from my brow as I finished tightening the last bolt on the conveyor. The machines had been running hotter than usual, and I knew skipping the last maintenance window was a mistake. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “We can’t afford another breakdown. Make sure everything’s spotless and running smooth before the shift ends.” I glanced at the clock—just half an hour until Friday prayers. I hurried to the washroom, scrubbing the grease from my hands, but the oil had seeped into my overalls and under my nails. 

I pulled out my clean shirt and trousers from my locker, but the grime clung stubbornly to my skin and sleeves. I hesitated, knowing the expectation to enter the prayer hall in clean, modest clothing. My heart pounded with anxiety. If I took more time to clean up, the machines might overheat again, risking a costly shutdown. But if I rushed, I’d enter the mosque not fully clean, falling short of the respect and modesty my faith demands. I stood there, torn between my duty to my job and my responsibility as a Muslim, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
